+Ayfex
Nah, not really. For the most part, during the Middle Ages in Europe, 
people didn't really have much of a concept of "race", as all populations 
were scaringly homogenous, racially. The only places where there was any 
heavy genetic mixing was in big trade centers like Venice, Huangzhou and 
Bagdad. Everywhere else, people of different races were seen as exotic, and 
as a curiosity, but not really as inferior. Think of the "circus freaks" 
from the 20th century, with dwarf strongmen, bearded women and siamese 
sisters and you get a better idea of what people in Europe thought of other 
races.
Regarding Jesus, people were just trying to describe him in a way they saw 
fit. Because they were so unused to seeing people of other races, it just 
made sense to describe Jesus as a white person, because that was all the 
vast majority of the population knew. Only with the Colonization Era did 
people really start to notice those other races around.

comments.text:
*Der 21. Mai ist der 141. Tag des gregorianischen Kalenders* (der 142. in 
Schaltjahren), somit verbleiben noch 224 Tage bis Jahresende. An diesem Tag 
beginnt das Tierkreiszeichen Zwillinge als Nachfolger auf den Stier.
Noch 22 Wochen und 3 Tage zur guten alten Zeitrechnung.

*Welttag der kulturellen Vielfalt für Dialog und Entwicklung*


Video-Wochenmotto: Symphony Of Science

Video des Tages:
A musical celebration of humanity, its origins, and achievements, 
contrasted with a somber look at our environmentally destructive tendencies 
and deep similarities with other primates. Featuring Jacob Bronowski, Alice 
Roberts, Carolyn Porco, Jane Goodall, Robert Sapolsky, Neil deGrasse Tyson 
and David Attenborough. "Children of Africa" is the tenth installment in 
the ongoing Symphony of Science music video series.

Ereignisse:
1502: Der portugiesische Seefahrer João da Nova entdeckt die Insel St. 
Helena im Südatlantik.
1871: Die von den Ingenieuren Niklaus Riggenbach, Ferdinand Adolf Naeff und 
Olivier Zschokke gebaute Rigibahn in der Schweiz, die erste Zahnradbahn 
Europas auf einen Berg, wird eröffnet.
1927: Nach 33,5 Stunden Alleinflug über den Atlantik landet Charles 
Lindbergh mit seiner Spirit of St. Louis auf dem Flughafen Le Bourget in 
Frankreich.
1932: Amelia Earhart muss nach dem ersten Alleinflug einer Frau über den 
Atlantik „auf Gallaghers Weide“ in der Nähe von Londonderry in Nordirland 
notlanden. Sie ist damit auch der erste Mensch, der zweimal den Atlantik 
überflogen hat.
1936: In Tokio wird Abe Sada von Polizisten festgenommen. In ihrer 
Handtasche befinden sich die abgetrennten Genitalien ihres Geliebten, den 
sie drei Tage zuvor beim erotischen Spiel stranguliert hat. Der Fall erregt 
nationales Aufsehen.
1967: In den USA wird aus dem Wellenreiten das Windsurfen entwickelt. Der 
Amerikaner Jim Drake startet in der Jamaica Bay in New York zum ersten Mal 
seinen aus einem Surfbrett und einem Segel bestehenden Windsurfer Old 
Yeller.
1972: Ein verwirrter Mann beschädigt in einem Akt von Vandalismus 
Michelangelos Pietà im Petersdom. Der Täter schlägt mit einem Hammer auf 
die Skulptur ein.

Geburtstage:
1471: Albrecht Dürer, deutscher Maler, Zeichner, Graphiker und 
Kunstschriftsteller
1844: Henri Rousseau, französischer Maler
1948: Leo Sayer, britischer Sänger und Songschreiber
1952: Mr. T, US-amerikanischer Schauspieler
1972: The Notorious B.I.G., US-amerikanischer Rap-Musiker
1973: Niels Ruf, deutscher Fernsehmoderator, Autor und Schauspieler
1977: Bodo Wartke, deutscher Kabarettist und Pianist

Todestage:
1965: Geoffrey de Havilland, britischer Flugpionier und Konstrukteur
1988: Sammy Davis Sr., US-amerikanischer Entertainer
2002: Niki de Saint Phalle, Malerin und Bildhauerin﻿

+KASASpace All elements come from hydrogen. After the Big Bang when protons 
and electrons came together from quarks, they formed hydrogen atoms. 
Hydrogen atoms prevailed in the cosmos for a long time, until clouds of 
hydrogen gas began to attract and come together. These clouds eventually 
became so massive that, in their center, hydrogen atoms were slammed into 
each other, fused together by the immense pressure, into a helium atom. And 
this releases a ton of energy, hence why stars  are so bright. Even larger 
stars managed to fuse together elements as large as iron. Elements above 
iron came about through supernovae. A supernova occurs when a large star 
collapses under its own weight, forcing a massive amount of matter into a 
tiny little space. Smashing these atoms together creates an immense nuclear 
fusion reaction, fusing elements higher than iron.
That's pretty much what he means.
All life is composed of atoms that originated from a star. 
We invent things, play video games, build cities, run governments. "These 
are some of the things that hydrogen atoms do, given fifteen billion years 
of cosmic evolution" (Carl Sagan, *Cosmos*, Chapter XIII).

comments.author: Patrick McGinnes

comments.text:
+Amelia Hartman 

http://news.discovery.com/human/evolution/neanderthals-modern-human-121101.htm

"The only modern populations without Neanderthal admixture are the 
sub-Saharan groups," said researcher Carles Lalueza-Fox, a paleogeneticist 
at the Institute of Evolutionary Biology at Barcelona, Spain.

http://humanorigins.si.edu/evidence/genetics/ancient-dna-and-neanderthals/sequencing-neanderthal-dna

"The Neanderthal sequence was compared to those of five modern humans from 
France, China, Papua New Guinea, as well as Africans from the San and 
Yoruba groups. Tests indicated that Neanderthals shared more derived 
alleles with non-African modern humans than with African modern humans. 
They compared parts of the Neanderthal genome with pairs of modern humans. 
While the European and Asian pairs had similar amounts of derived material 
compared with the Neanderthal, Neanderthals had more similarities with 
non-African humans than with Africans. The simplest explanation for these 
results is gene flow from Neanderthals into modern humans. Gene flow could 
also have occurred from modern humans into Neanderthals. Interbreeding 
events between Neanderthals and modern humans might be obscured if the 
modern human population was large."
comments.author: Patrick McGinnes

comments.text:
+Patrick McGinnes Well then your "opinion" is simply wrong. Neanderthals 
were an entirely different species from us. It is *not* true *in the 
slightest* that "mixed blood African have Neanderthal D.N.A.". All humans 
alive today are all related to Neanderthals the same exact way: as cousins. 
Not a single one human alive today is "more related" to Neanderthals than 
another. *Not a single one* "descended" from Neanderthals. 
Neanderthals were an entirely different species that died out.
